image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian and Daryl Maguire.

image.altText: Vladimir Putin and Sergei Shoigu wear hats but no shirts as they lounge on a lakeside dock.

items.synopsis: Sergei Shoigu, Vladimir Putin's longtime defence minister and close confidant, has so far held onto his position and survived an all-out mutiny staged by one of his most powerful opponents.

title.children: In the game of thrones currently unfolding at the Kremlin, one man just keeps holding on

image.altText: A feral cat

items.synopsis: A remote shire says the state government has a gaping hole in its multi-million-dollar strategy to protect wildlife from feral cats. It's the legislated right for pet cats to wander.

title.children: WA is spending millions on a plan to kill feral cats. So why are pet cats allowed to roam the streets?

image.altText: Nathan Lyon looks upset as he sits with a team doctor outside the boundary rope

items.synopsis: England's response to Australia's short-pitched bowling brings the second Test at Lord's to life, but it's Nathan Lyon's calf injury that could yet have the biggest say in this Ashes series, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: As an injured and emotional Lyon left Lord's, Australia was forced into an unexpected back up plan

image.altText: Australian players celebrate with Mitchell Starc after a wicket

image.altText: A woman smiles and holds up four Taylor Swift records in front of her.

image.altText: Erin

items.synopsis: Experts warn a culture of disbelief in Australia's family court system is resulting in children being sent to live with their alleged abusers, leaving them with lifelong consequences.

title.children: Erin told a family court report writer her father abused her. She was then forced to live with him full time

image.altText: A man and a woman at their wedding. She is in a white wedding dress, he is in a wedding suit with sunglasses.

items.synopsis: A number of "items of interest" are recovered from a disused gold mine amid what police are now calling an unsolved double murder case in the Western Australian Mid West.

image.altText: A map of Victoria showing

items.synopsis: Thousands of people report feeling the effects of an early morning earthquake in Victoria's High Country, which seismologists say may be a part of a sequence that began in 2021.

title.children: Tremors felt in Melbourne as magnitude-4.6 earthquake strikes Victoria

image.altText: NAIDOC Week Finalists: Donnell Wallam, Aaron Fa'aoso and Rachel Perkins

items.synopsis: From a pool of almost 200 nominees, meet this year's 2023 National NAIDOC Week Award finalists.

image.altText: Close up of a sign advertising a house for sale in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: An increasing number of Australians are selling homes that they have owned for fewer than two years, many at a loss, and analysts warn it might be an early sign of mortgage distress.

title.children: More recent buyers are reselling their homes, and that may be an early sign of mortgage troubles

image.altText: A view of a lage building with flags on top

items.synopsis: Stronger than expected economic data out of the US suggests its central bank will resume its "moderate pace of interest rate decisions" at its next meeting, while European markets gained after inflation data and profit figures. Follow live.

title.children: US Federal Reserve expects 'moderate' rate rises to resume, H&M shares soar as profit jumps, ASX to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's stay with the US for a moment and with Fed chairman Jerome Powell's comments about interest rates in Madrid. While attending an event held by Spain's central bank, he said the Fed expects "the moderate pace of interest rate decisions to continue" after a pause earlier this month. Before pausing, the Fed had hiked rates in 10 straight meetings, leaving the rate between 5-5.25% range — which it said would give them time to assess the lag of rate hikes and manage the aftershocks of the US bank stresses. But the US labour market remains tight at 3.7% and inflation remains a big concern for the Fed, even though it's down from its peak. "Inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go," Powell told the event in Madrid. He also said he wasn't alone in his thinking — he told the event a "strong majority" of policymakers at the Fed think there's at least two more rate rises coming by the year's end. There's only four more policy meetings this year, with the next one at the end of July. The Fed's inflation target is 2%, with US inflation double that at 4.1% in May.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Strong majority' of Fed members in favour of at least two more rate hikes in US

children.content: Let's stay with the US for a moment and with Fed chairman Jerome Powell's comments about interest rates in Madrid.
While attending an event held by Spain's central bank, he said the Fed expects "the moderate pace of interest rate decisions to continue" after a pause earlier this month.

Before pausing, the Fed had hiked rates in 10 straight meetings, leaving the rate between 5-5.25% range — which it said would give them time to assess the lag of rate hikes and manage the aftershocks of the US bank stresses.
But the US labour market remains tight at 3.7% and inflation remains a big concern for the Fed, even though it's down from its peak.
"Inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go," Powell told the event in Madrid.
He also said he wasn't alone in his thinking — he told the event a "strong majority" of policymakers at the Fed think there's at least two more rate rises coming by the year's end.
There's only four more policy meetings this year, with the next one at the end of July.
The Fed's inflation target is 2%, with US inflation double that at 4.1% in May.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Financial crime regulator AUSTRAC will take no further action against Bell Financial Group after finalising its external audit of the company. Last February, AUSTRAC appointed an external auditor to examine Bell Financial's three entities (Bell Potter Securities, Bell Potter Capital and Third Party Platform ) to examine their compliance with with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws. AUSTRAC has since been handed the final audit report, and has decided not to take any further regulatory action against the entities — finalising the external audit process. "AUSTRAC has reiterated the importance for Bell to meet its compliance obligations in the future, and will continue to work with Bell to ensure ongoing compliance, and to monitor the remediation and uplift undertaken by the entities in response to the external auditor findings and recommendations," the regulator said in a statement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AUSTRAC to take no further action against Bell Financial Group

children.content: Financial crime regulator AUSTRAC will take no further action against Bell Financial Group after finalising its external audit of the company.

Last February, AUSTRAC appointed an external auditor to examine Bell Financial's three entities (Bell Potter Securities, Bell Potter Capital and Third Party Platform ) to examine their compliance with with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws.
AUSTRAC has since been handed the final audit report, and has decided not to take any further regulatory action against the entities — finalising the external audit process.

"AUSTRAC has reiterated the importance for Bell to meet its compliance obligations in the future, and will continue to work with Bell to ensure ongoing compliance, and to monitor the remediation and uplift undertaken by the entities in response to the external auditor findings and recommendations," the regulator said in a statement.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're in the depths of winter here in Australia, but let's take a quick (virtual) journey to summery Europe. Here's a quick roundup of major developments over there while we were sleeping: The STOXX 600 edged up, led by major gains for Swedish retailer H & M — the company posted stronger than expected profits for Q2, and sent their share price soaring by 18.2% as a result (more on this a bit later) Inflation in Germany rose by 6.8% in June, more than economists were predicting — although some analysts believe it's a blip in what's otherwise been a steady decline Sticking with inflation, it's dropped to 1.9% in Spain in June, making it the slowest increase in the country since March 2021. It also makes Spain one of the first major European economies to dip below 2%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation rises in Germany, but falls below 2pc in Spain

children.content: We're in the depths of winter here in Australia, but let's take a quick (virtual) journey to summery Europe.
Here's a quick roundup of major developments over there while we were sleeping:
The STOXX 600 edged up, led by
major gains for Swedish retailer H
M
— the company posted stronger than expected profits for Q2, and sent their share price soaring by 18.2% as a result (more on this a bit later)
Inflation in Germany rose by 6.8% in June
, more than economists were predicting — although some analysts believe it's a blip in what's otherwise been a steady decline
Sticking with
inflation, it's dropped to 1.9% in Spain
in June, making it the slowest increase in the country since March 2021. It also makes Spain one of the first major European economies to dip below 2%

image.altText: Gloved hand holding genetic test tube

items.synopsis: Life insurance companies are accused of "genetic discrimination" in determining coverage and premiums, with researchers finding some Australians are skipping tests that could detect risk of disease to avoid the results affecting their life insurance.

title.children: Australians skipping genetic screening tests out of fear it will affect life insurance coverage

image.altText: Shyanne-Lee Tatnell CCTV thumb

items.synopsis: Tasmania Police have released CCTV footage showing the last known movements of teenager Shyanne-Lee Tatnell, who has now been missing for two months. They have also narrowed down the vehicles of interest to just one.

title.children: Police release CCTV of missing Tasmanian teen, continue search for mystery car

image.altText: Smoke is seen around a deflated balloon against a clear blue sky

items.synopsis: The flight marked a long-delayed breakthrough for the company after 20 years of development setbacks.

title.children: Branson's rocket plane takes its first paying passengers to the edge of space

image.altText: Scot Peterson clasping his hands together, weeping, as the verdict is read aloud in court.

image.altText: A middle-aged man with brown hair and stubble takes a selfie on top of a high mountain range in Iraq.

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian.

items.synopsis: The significance of the findings against Gladys Berejiklian shouldn’t be lost, even if the fallout and political impacts appear minimal.

title.children: What lessons can be learnt from the Gladys Berejiklian corruption investigation?

image.altText: composite images of Daryl Maguire and a bag and wads of cash spread out on a table.

image.altText: A police car and police tape is seen in front of a house

image.altText: A woman in all white follows through with her racquet after playing a forehand shot.

image.altText: A woman with dark hair stands, arms crossed, against a wall in a kitchen with pots and pans behind her

items.synopsis: Last year, a cap on the hours international students could work was lifted to help counter COVID workforce shortages. It's being reinstated from July — and employers and students are worried.

image.altText: Sunak speaks in front of a lectern emblazoned with the slogan 'stop the boats'

title.children: 'Your government should decide who comes here': Sunak reacts after court rules Rwanda asylum plan unlawful

image.altText: A Papua New Guinean man wearing singlet and headphones around neck points to the sky with island and water in background

items.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's chief censor has temporarily banned venues and broadcasters from playing music by a controversial local singer after a complaint several songs contain "emotionally triggering lyrics", but how the tracks are triggering remains unclear.

title.children: PNG bans 'emotionally triggering' music by popular artist Jayrex
